text:
The iPhone5S launch features a new fingerprint
sensor built into the home button to lock
and unlock your phone.

nine million have already been shipped in
just a week and Americans are reportedly set

up their phone to be unlocked using their
tongues, cat's paws and in some cases their
nipples which doesn't sound very practical.

But you would think using your fingerprint
to secure your phone which would be a really
smart solution.

However within a day of the product launching
an organisation in Germany called the Chaos

Computer Club claimed that they hacked Apple's
touch ID system.
So how did they go about doing this?
Is it a hard thing to do?

Well fingerprinting itself or Dactyloscopy
which is not easy to say and is worth 25 points

in scrabble is actually a really good way
of identifying people,

it's better even than DNA which is shared
of course by identical twins.

There have been no two people found with an
identical fingerprint.

And the statistics suggest that there is a
1 in 64 billion chance of having the same
fingerprint as somebody else.

Now most of our body is covered in smooth
skin, but it's just our hands and our feet

that have ridges over the entire surface and
that's thought to be to help the sense of

touch,
the feel of friction, but also to help us
grip things.

And these ridges actually form in the womb,
so up until about 20 weeks, as we grow fingers

and nails the skin is forming these ridges,
and at 20 weeks it's fixed and those patters
stay with us for the rest of our lives.

So if you were to look at your fingertips,
your finger print, you would likely see one
of three patterns.

Firstly you might see an arch which is an
undulation in the ridges, secondly you might

see a loop and the loop might veer off towards
your thumb or slightly of towards your little
finger.

And the third feature to look for is a spiral
or a whorl, it's spelt WHORL.

So if it's so hard to map and to see your
finger is so complicated, how did these guys
in Germany manage to hack the system?

Well they didn't chop anybody's finger off
and Apple are being very very careful to make

sure the technology wouldn't work if you tried
that.

What they did do was manage to get hold of
an image of somebody's fingerprint.

Now what they say, their method, their claim
is as follows.

If you get hold of an image you need to scan
it or take an image at a very high resolution

at 2400dpi, you then take the image and pass
it through something like photoshop, clean

it up, and invert the image, and then you
need to print it at 1200dpi on a lazier printer
with a very high toner thickness.

If you print that on an acetate or something
with a shiny finish, you then as a final step

paint that with a latex or a PVA glue or something
that will set rubbery, leave it to dry, leave

it to set and then peel it off and you'll
have the undulations, the curve of the original

print,
if you place it on your finger you can then

place it on the phone, and you will unlock
the fingerprint sensor.

And this has been shown on a number of videos
posted on YouTube by this organisation.

Apple of course are fighting to keep up, I'm
sure they will come up with a solution to

that and we will keep our finger on the pulse
to make sure we're aware of any development

and we'll bring them to you and we will clean
our fingerprints off anything we've touched
in the meantime.

If you want to subscribe to Head Squeeze you
know the drill just click on
the subscribe button.
